Review: Hedgepig Theatre's 'Miss Julie'

By James Bithell

August Strindberg's 1880 masterpiece about the class struggle is reincarnated into the roaring twenties world of sensuality and scandal, in Andy Curry's touring production of Miss Julie. Jordan Licht reviews.

Review: Cover Up

By James Bithell

Student written play, Cover Up entertained through-out, bringing the Barn audience an unravelling tale of deception and disgrace. Lucie Parker reviews.

Get Your Fix: What's On

By James Bithell

Editor's picks of local art attractions.

Review: The Horologicon

By James Bithell

A book to be savoured and enjoyed, The Horologicon provides you with all the most fabulous and yet useless words you could ever want. Poppy Bullard reviews.

Review: Is It Just Me!

By James Bithell

Awkward and hilarious, award-winning comic has scored a hit with this light and frivolous autobiography.

Review: The Aftermath Exhibition

By James Bithell

A varied and unusual exhibition, 'The Aftermath Exhibition' is well-worth the venture to the top of Micklegate. Carys Brain reviews.

Review: The Making of Landscape

An all-star cast boasting some of the world's greatest Landscape artists, The Making of Landscape leaves you feeling unexpectedly cheated. Roisin Astell reviews.

Review: A Slap in the Face

By James Bithell

Drama Barn's first offering this term is an impressive performance, but leaves much to be desired. Lizzie Stephens reviews.

Video Review: The Settlers

The Norman Rea Gallery reveal their latest exhibition, The Settlers. Poppy Bullard reviews.

Review: Junior Officers' Reading Club - Patrick Hennesy

By James Bithell

The Junior Officer's Reading Club bridges a long unspoken gap between civilian and soldier, giving a transparent, comic, and brutally honest explanation supporting those either side of the divide. Poppy Bullard reviews.

Portrait of a Lady

Paul Emsley's attempt at photorealism in his recent portrait of the Duchess of Cambridge has Aggie Torrance unconvinced.

Review: La Boheme

By James Bithell

The Royal Opera House hosts an opera in four acts which transported the audience to the centre of Parisian romance, with a stunning set and acting to match.

Review: The Orb

A great opportunity to experience the medieval stained-glass in the Minster as never before. Carys Brain reviews.

Review: Robin Hood and his Merry Mam!

Camp, colourful and slightly confusing, Carys Brain reviews.

Review: Fresher's Plays - Vera and The Cherry Orchard

Brilliant new talent is showcased in this term's Fresher's Plays. Nouse reviews.

Review: Greenland

A strong cast took on a challenging production of Howard Brenton's Utopian drama, but a lack of relevance and execution dogged the production. Paapa Mills-Bampoe reviews.

Review: An Evening of Contemporary Human Rights Poetry

Review: YorSecret

Sold as a welfare event, YorSecret proves a brave and thought-provoking exhibition. Mihaela Nemes reviews.

Review: The Nutcracker

The Vienna Festival Ballet were hosted by the Grand Opera House. The dance and movement caught the magic of the Christmas, but the lack of orchestra failed to charm.

Review: Sitting Room Comedy

Dana Alexander was a highlight in a line-up of well-chosen acts, but the long sets left some performers lacking spark.

Review: Bloody Poetry

An astonishingly unique and provocatively philosophical show that will not fail to entertain. Thomas Cox reviews.

Review: Birdsong

An outstanding piece of Drama Barn theatre that perfectly captures the tumultuous dynamics of World War One. Lucie Parker reviews.

Review: Miss Hazard

Lucy Dickens reviews the Norman Rea's latest exhibition, 'Miss Hazard.'

Review: Les Miserables

Les Miserables without the music. It sounds like a recipe for disaster. Celia Scruby finds the outcome to be quite the reverse.

Review: Hansel and Gretel & The Shambles

Laura Stratford reviews the Christmas panto, Hansel and Gretel, finding it full of the usual well-loved parodies and side-splitting humour.

Arts in York: what's on

A roundup of the interesting, the exciting, and the not-to-be-missed in York (Thumbnail credit Sebastian Faulk's Birdsong)

Review: The Hot Mikado

By James Bithell

"The most fun you'll have in the theatre all year". This is a play that doesn't aim to take itself too seriously. Tom Giles Reviews.

Review: Calendar Girls

Tim Firth's heart-warming adaptation of the famous film Calendar Girls leaves a new found belief in humanity. Lucie Parker reviews.

Review: Lady Lovely Lute

The Open Drama Night has produced an intriguing and insightful documentary, in which intimacy and intelligence is brought to a girl's experiences of brain trauma. Poppy Bullard reviews.

Review: The Hunchback of Notre Dame

Calvitto offers an adaptation of Victor Hugo's dark tale, effectively bringing out Quasimodo's psychological affliction. Catriona Lacy reviews.
